urls.title: Announcing new manage Likes endpoints for theTwitter API v2
urls.description: Liking Tweets is one of the foundational ways people engage in the public conversation on Twitter. We are excited to announce the launch of manage Likes in the Twitter API v2. Now you can use the v2 API to like and unlike Tweets. The manage Likes endpoints enable you to like or unlike a specified Tweet on behalf of an authenticated account. For these endpoints, there are two methods available, POST and DELETE. The POST method allows you to like a Tweet, and the DELETE method enables you to unli...

urls.title: Announcing Twitter API v2 Likes lookup and blocks lookup
urls.description: Today, we are excited to announce the launch of Likes and blocks lookup endpoints. This release brings the Twitter API v2 a little bit closer to achieving v1.1 parity and delivers net new Likes functionality, only available on v2. Likes lookup Liking Tweets is one of the core features people use to engage in the public conversation on Twitter. With endpoints in our Likes lookup endpoint group, you can see a list of accounts that have liked a specified Tweet, or which Tweets a specified account...

urls.title: academictwitteR: Access the Twitter Academic Research Product Track V2 API Endpoint
urls.description: Package to query the Twitter Academic Research Product Track, providing access to full-archive search and other v2 API endpoints. Functions are written with academic research in mind. They provide flexibility in how the user wishes to store collected data, and encourage regular storage of data to mitigate loss when collecting large volumes of tweets. They also provide workarounds to manage and reshape the format in which data is provided on the client side.

text:
Introducing the manage Likes endpoints to the #TwitterAPI v2. Liking Tweets is one of the core aspects of the Twitter experience. Developers can now use these endpoints to like or unlike a specified Tweet on behalf of an authenticated account.

https://t.co/VCWYEHN8Bf

urls.title: Announcing new manage Likes endpoints for theTwitter API v2
urls.description: Liking Tweets is one of the foundational ways people engage in the public conversation on Twitter. We are excited to announce the launch of manage Likes in the Twitter API v2. Now you can use the v2 API to like and unlike Tweets. The manage Likes endpoints enable you to like or unlike a specified Tweet on behalf of an authenticated account. For these endpoints, there are two methods available, POST and DELETE. The POST method allows you to like a Tweet, and the DELETE method enables you to unli...

text: The team met at UC Berkeley. “We made countless nonsensical projects at hackathons, but we soon realized the Twitter API offers us a tangible opportunity to make an impact with the projects we’re building.”

referenced_tweets.text: “With an ongoing heightened climate crisis, wildfires have become increasingly widespread and unpredictable,” say @austinge0rge @Neel88828098 @j_adrineda from @firetalkteam. “We sought to build an all-in-one resource that would keep people updated.”

Fire Talk provides users with centralized information on local fires. It uses the #TwitterAPI to show Tweets relevant to your location, complemented with other data like air quality index and local news. https://t.co/TVZDFOflzR

text: “I have been a developer from a young age,” says @yesnoornext. @marie_dm_ “started coding in engineering school, where I discovered a strong interest in tech. We always wanted to create something that can help people to follow things they love and save information that matters.”

referenced_tweets.text: “The idea of Threader came from the desire to highlight the amazing stories and knowledge shared on Twitter,” explain @marie_dm_ and @yesnoornext. “As threads became popular, they were hard to find or read. We decided to build an app to retrieve and save this great content.”

text: “I always wanted my work to speak for me, and be out there for others in the world to use and admire,” says @JPEGuin. “It fills me with a sense of accomplishment to be able to see people use my products, and liking them, after putting in countless hours of hard work and effort.”

referenced_tweets.text: Building on the newest features of both the #TwitterAPI and iOS was the inspiration for @JPEGuin, creator of @AviaryTheApp. “I wanted to make something that uses the latest iOS 14 features, whilst being fully feature-rich so users can make the most of it.”

mentions.description: App Store featured  app developer. Ex-IBM. Currently working on a variety of apps including @AviaryTheApp and @VinylsTheApp.
mentions.name: Shihab Mehboob

mentions.description:
A beautiful and feature-rich App Store featured Twitter app for iOS, iPadOS, watchOS, and macOS.

For feedback and bug reports, get in touch with @JPEGuin.
mentions.name: Aviary

referenced_tweets.text: Meet Aviary, a modern client for iOS 14 built using the new Twitter API. It has a beautiful UI and great widgets to keep you up to date with the latest Tweets. https://t.co/95cbd253jK

text:
This change will help us focus on delivering value to the >99% of people currently using Profiles & Lists timelines. You should see these features become faster, easier to use, and more up-to-date with Twitter features and functionality. 

Learn more 📖

https://t.co/HzeJLglpRn

referenced_tweets.text: During our analysis, we discovered only 0.52% of domains use the Likes timeline, Collections timeline, and Moments timeline. Because of the very low usage, we plan to retire these timelines on June 23, 2021.

Embedded timelines are a great way to add a set of Tweets (known as a timeline) to your own website. As Twitter continues to improve our underlying systems, we performed an analysis of the various embeddable timelines available. 🧮

text: During our analysis, we discovered only 0.52% of domains use the Likes timeline, Collections timeline, and Moments timeline. Because of the very low usage, we plan to retire these timelines on June 23, 2021.

referenced_tweets.text: Embedded timelines are a great way to add a set of Tweets (known as a timeline) to your own website. As Twitter continues to improve our underlying systems, we performed an analysis of the various embeddable timelines available. 🧮

text: “To quote my creator Jerome Gangneux, I always struggled to read Twitter threads on the original service; I think it would have been better to put Tweets one after another in a separate page. And that’s how I was born”.

referenced_tweets.text: “In the 20th century, managers managed humans, but in the 21st century, humans will manage robots. It is my aim to make this as painless a transition as possible,” says the bot. “I have observed that humans do things very slowly, but I can do things faster – and I am tireless!”
Meet one of the useful Twitter bots out there: @ThreadReaderApp, unroll! It makes threads like this easier to read and share. Today, we’ll hear from the bot itself! https://t.co/tBFlJB3m3o

mentions.description: I'm a 🤖 to help you read threads more easily. Reply to any tweet of a thread and mention me with the "unroll" keyword and I'll give you a link back 😀

text:
We’re excited to support so many more research possibilities with this track - both today, and for years to come. 
 
What do you plan to discover next with Twitter data? 🔎  Let us know!

referenced_tweets.text:
We know this doesn't represent everyone doing research with Twitter data, so we're building solutions to support the full range of research use cases. Today’s release is just the start of much more to come this year, for all our developers.

👀 the roadmap
https://t.co/rspek8Ph9t

To be eligible for this track, you need to:
• Be a master’s student, PhD, post-doc, faculty, or employee at an academic institution,
• Have a clearly defined research objective, and
• Use this only for non-commercial purposes.
 
More here 👇
https://t.co/GDSZq9LvE5

text:
To be eligible for this track, you need to:
• Be a master’s student, PhD, post-doc, faculty, or employee at an academic institution,
• Have a clearly defined research objective, and
• Use this only for non-commercial purposes.
 
More here 👇
https://t.co/GDSZq9LvE5

• Advanced filtering ability 🔍
• Technical resources 🧑‍💻 
• And all available for free 🎉

urls.title: Enabling study of the public conversation in a time of crisis
urls.description: To further support our company’s ongoing efforts, we want to enable developers and researchers to study the public conversation on COVID-19 in real-time.

referenced_tweets.text:
During these unprecedented times, what’s happening on Twitter can help the world better understand & respond to the pandemic. 

We're launching a free COVID-19 stream endpoint so qualified devs & researchers can study the public conversation in real-time. https://t.co/BPqMcQzhId

Since its launch a few weeks ago, there’s been a lot of interest in the COVID-19 stream endpoint. Today we want to share more about the applications we've seen so far and how we’re reviewing them. https://t.co/acVQ1M0O9f

urls.title: Designing the new Engage endpoints
urls.description: People come to Twitter to connect and interact with each other, with their favorite teams, celebrities, brands, or musicians, with world leaders, with their communities, and more. Whether it’s creating engaging content of your own, or building solutions that allow others to engage, developers play a critical role in how people connect and interact on Twitter. Today, we’re excited to share our early thinking for how we’re designing new endpoints for the Engage use case; specifically the endpoint...

Lots of great comedy TV recs in the thread below. I wanted to write a script that used Twitter's API to fetch replies so that I could count how many mentions/likes each TV show got.  

However, it looks like Twitter's API doesn't support seeing replies to a tweet? That's bonkers. https://t.co/R0vpcJfJe5

@lpolovets 👋 hey hey... just replying to say you should check out our new `conversation_id` operator. This operator makes it possible to easily retrieve complete conversation threads. 💬

https://t.co/5zt8cdqauG

referenced_tweets.text:
It’s finally here! 🥁 Say hello to the new #TwitterAPI.

We’re rebuilding the Twitter API v2 from the ground up to better serve our developer community. And today’s launch is only the beginning.

https://t.co/32VrwpGaJw https://t.co/KaFSbjWUA8

Today we launched the new #TwitterAPI v2 - the most significant rebuild of our API since 2012. We’re sharing what went into rebuilding the Twitter API: https://t.co/LV79IX4aYV🧵 1/6 https://t.co/5NpvzZR02g

author.name: Twitter Engineering

referenced_tweets.text:
Everything released today is in Early Access - meaning it's production-ready.

In the future, when all v2 endpoints are available, this API will replace the v1.1 standard, premium, and enterprise endpoints. We’ll announce deprecations with plenty of notice as v2 takes shape.

Today marks the beginning of a new era for the #TwitterAPI. 

Visit our new developer portal to get started. We can’t wait to hear what you think.

https://t.co/3nGKgesmvf

We’re committed to building the new API in the open. You can expect to see: 

⏩ A modern API foundation
⏩ Features to better understand & engage with the conversation
⏩ Tailored product tracks & access levels
+ so much more

Check out our roadmap ⬇️ https://t.co/rspek8Ph9t

Everything released today is in Early Access - meaning it's production-ready.

In the future, when all v2 endpoints are available, this API will replace the v1.1 standard, premium, and enterprise endpoints. We’ll announce deprecations with plenty of notice as v2 takes shape.

author.name: Twitter Dev
author.description: The voice of the #TwitterDev team and your official source for updates, news, and events, related to the #TwitterAPI.

referenced_tweets.text:
In 2012, a year after our official docs launched, v1.1 was released. This was the first major update to the #TwitterAPI in 6 years.

Since then, we've introduced premium and enterprise access, but the v1.1 foundations remain the same... but that won't be the case forever.

Last year, we adopted a new approach - building our 🆕 API in the open with the launch of Twitter Developer Labs.

With Labs, you can test new endpoints and features before they launch. Here’s a recap of what we’ve learned over the last year.

https://t.co/Lu7BFJpdCI

author.name: Twitter Dev
author.description: The voice of the #TwitterDev team and your official source for updates, news, and events, related to the #TwitterAPI.

in_reply_to_user.name: Twitter Dev
in_reply_to_user.description: The voice of the #TwitterDev team and your official source for updates, news, and events, related to the #TwitterAPI.

text:
Thank you to all of you who have engaged with us and shared your feedback. Your input has been vital, and we’re committed to continuing these conversations with you.  

There’s so much more we’re doing to build a better #TwitterAPI… and Early Access is coming tomorrow! ✨

In 2011 our official #TwitterAPI documentation site launched. Up until then, developers were using Google Groups for discussions and solving problems. 👀

https://t.co/LAkk4mAHkw

In 2012, a year after our official docs launched, v1.1 was released. This was the first major update to the #TwitterAPI in 6 years.

Since then, we've introduced premium and enterprise access, but the v1.1 foundations remain the same... but that won't be the case forever.

text:
Last year, we adopted a new approach - building our 🆕 API in the open with the launch of Twitter Developer Labs.

With Labs, you can test new endpoints and features before they launch. Here’s a recap of what we’ve learned over the last year.

https://t.co/Lu7BFJpdCI

Twurl, Twitter’s curl-like application, arrived in 2009. Twurl is specifically tailored for the #TwitterAPI — seriously, you can do so much with Twurl. It’s like the Swiss Army Knife for the Twitter APIs.

https://t.co/1sFYk2G3Jb

In 2011 our official #TwitterAPI documentation site launched. Up until then, developers were using Google Groups for discussions and solving problems. 👀

https://t.co/LAkk4mAHkw

text:
In 2012, a year after our official docs launched, v1.1 was released. This was the first major update to the #TwitterAPI in 6 years.

Since then, we've introduced premium and enterprise access, but the v1.1 foundations remain the same... but that won't be the case forever.

referenced_tweets.text:
“My application was rejected. Why?”
 
This can happen for a number of reasons. The most common are not having the technical capability/plans for high data volume, lack of details in the app, unclear use for public good, or privacy concerns with how this data will be used/shared.

If you aren’t approved for the COVID-19 stream, you may be able to use our free filtered stream with an approved dev account. You must update your use case & still need to comply with our terms. Our docs share how to create a similar filter on COVID-19 👇
https://t.co/TBCy8VaiSS

referenced_tweets.text:
97% of those approved so far are researchers. 🔎

Most often, they want to study how misinformation spreads, public perceptions of policies or official statements, or long-term impacts of the virus on mental health, vulnerable communities, & social behavior.

Our teams review each application thoughtfully to understand:

1️⃣ Technical resources/plans to handle high data volume
2️⃣ How the proposed use case serves the public good 
3️⃣ Past & planned adherence to our terms (linked ⬇️)
https://t.co/PPvVCmK24i

referenced_tweets.text:
Applications, by the numbers 📊

🌏🌍🌎35+ countries are represented by all applicants
🎓70% are academic researchers
💼18% are commercial & non-commercial orgs
🧑‍💻12% are independent developers and/or researchers
 
We are not limiting how many can be approved to use this data.

97% of those approved so far are researchers. 🔎

Most often, they want to study how misinformation spreads, public perceptions of policies or official statements, or long-term impacts of the virus on mental health, vulnerable communities, & social behavior.

text:
Our teams review each application thoughtfully to understand:

1️⃣ Technical resources/plans to handle high data volume
2️⃣ How the proposed use case serves the public good 
3️⃣ Past & planned adherence to our terms (linked ⬇️)
https://t.co/PPvVCmK24i

urls.title: Enabling study of the public conversation in a time of crisis
urls.description: To further support our company’s ongoing efforts, we want to enable developers and researchers to study the public conversation on COVID-19 in real-time.

referenced_tweets.text:
During these unprecedented times, what’s happening on Twitter can help the world better understand & respond to the pandemic. 

We're launching a free COVID-19 stream endpoint so qualified devs & researchers can study the public conversation in real-time. https://t.co/BPqMcQzhId

Since its launch a few weeks ago, there’s been a lot of interest in the COVID-19 stream endpoint. Today we want to share more about the applications we've seen so far and how we’re reviewing them. https://t.co/acVQ1M0O9f

urls.title: Longer than usual developer account application response time
urls.description: As the world faces an unprecedented public health emergency, we want to be open about the challenges we are facing. As we work to keep our employees safe during COVID-19, new developers that are applying for a developer account are likely to experience a longer review time than anticipated. We are working to optimize internally and reduce the review time. In the meantime, we want to be open and set expectations for those who may have applied recently or will apply soon. Application reviews need...

referenced_tweets.text: You may have seen the recent announcement about following Topics on Twitter. Today, we’re excited to provide API support for this new feature. We're adding annotations to the payload, so you can discover new details about the Tweets that matter. 🧵https://t.co/B8613P9K5c https://t.co/PCJ9Wsi56V

A few months ago, we added Tweet annotations to the Labs’ streaming endpoints. These annotations help uncover details about topics within Tweets. 

Today, we’re adding annotations to all Tweet objects delivered in Labs. https://t.co/63pC4BDr5v

referenced_tweets.text: We’re adding some new requirements for bot accounts.  A bot is an account where behaviors like creating, publishing, and interacting with Tweets or Direct Messages are automated in some way through our API.

Our new policy asks that developers clearly indicate if they are operating a bot account, what the account is, and who the person behind it is. 🤖A couple of good examples of developers who are already doing this are: @everycolorbot and @earthquakesSF
https://t.co/xSQIX5ImnH

referenced_tweets.text:
We ❤️ the incredible research people do using Twitter data to study topics like spam, abuse, and other areas related to the health of conversation on Twitter.

Lots of great comedy TV recs in the thread below. I wanted to write a script that used Twitter's API to fetch replies so that I could count how many mentions/likes each TV show got.  

However, it looks like Twitter's API doesn't support seeing replies to a tweet? That's bonkers. https://t.co/R0vpcJfJe5

author.description: The voice of the #TwitterDev team and your official source for updates, news, and events, related to the #TwitterAPI.

referenced_tweets.text:
We’re committed to building the new API in the open. You can expect to see: 

⏩ A modern API foundation
⏩ Features to better understand & engage with the conversation
⏩ Tailored product tracks & access levels
+ so much more

Check out our roadmap ⬇️ https://t.co/rspek8Ph9t

Everything released today is in Early Access - meaning it's production-ready.

In the future, when all v2 endpoints are available, this API will replace the v1.1 standard, premium, and enterprise endpoints. We’ll announce deprecations with plenty of notice as v2 takes shape.

referenced_tweets.text:
“My application was rejected. Why?”
 
This can happen for a number of reasons. The most common are not having the technical capability/plans for high data volume, lack of details in the app, unclear use for public good, or privacy concerns with how this data will be used/shared.

text:
“My application was rejected. Why?”
 
This can happen for a number of reasons. The most common are not having the technical capability/plans for high data volume, lack of details in the app, unclear use for public good, or privacy concerns with how this data will be used/shared.

referenced_tweets.text:
“My application was approved. Now what?”
 
If you have access to this endpoint, consider sharing your learnings, methods and tools with the broader academic research community on our forum 👇
https://t.co/3mhry6dyeP

Our teams review each application thoughtfully to understand:

1️⃣ Technical resources/plans to handle high data volume
2️⃣ How the proposed use case serves the public good 
3️⃣ Past & planned adherence to our terms (linked ⬇️)
https://t.co/PPvVCmK24i

urls.title: Longer than usual developer account application response time
urls.description: As the world faces an unprecedented public health emergency, we want to be open about the challenges we are facing. As we work to keep our employees safe during COVID-19, new developers that are applying for a developer account are likely to experience a longer review time than anticipated. We are working to optimize internally and reduce the review time. In the meantime, we want to be open and set expectations for those who may have applied recently or will apply soon. Application reviews need...

text: We encourage all developers to take a look at this new policy and let us know if anything doesn’t make sense. https://t.co/tmArw75Swk

referenced_tweets.text:
Our new policy asks that developers clearly indicate if they are operating a bot account, what the account is, and who the person behind it is. 🤖A couple of good examples of developers who are already doing this are: @everycolorbot and @earthquakesSF
https://t.co/xSQIX5ImnH

mentions.name: Every Color
mentions.description: colors.  all of 'em. | developed by @vogon; feel free to send him feedback/feature requests

mentions.name: SF QuakeBot
mentions.description: I am a robot that live-tweets earthquakes in the San Francisco Bay area. Built by @billsnitzer. Data is from the USGS. Get prepared: http://t.co/VtCEbuw6KH

referenced_tweets.text: We’re adding some new requirements for bot accounts.  A bot is an account where behaviors like creating, publishing, and interacting with Tweets or Direct Messages are automated in some way through our API.
